It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit or distribute any handbill in or upon any private premises, except by handing or transmitting such handbill directly to the occupant of such private premises; provided, however, that in case of private premises which are not posted against the receiving of handbills or similar material, such person, unless requested by anyone upon such premises not to do so, may securely place such handbill in such a manner as to prevent such handbill from being carried by the elements about or upon the premises, any other public place or private premises, except mailboxes may not be so used when prohibited by federal postal law or regulations. (Code 1977, § 31-121(9)(b)) Sec. 46-91. - Exemption for newspapers and political literature. The provisions of this division shall not apply to the distribution upon private premises only of newspapers or political literature, except that newspapers and political literature shall be placed in such a manner as to prevent their being carried or deposited by the elements upon any public place, including street or road rights-of-way or adjoining private premises. A commercial handbill does not become a newspaper by containing some reading or pictorial matter other than advertising matter so long as the advertising matter plainly predominates over the nonadvertising matter. (Code 1977, § 31-121(9)(b)) Sec. 46-92. - Placing on vehicles. It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit any handbill in or upon any vehicle unless the occupant of such vehicle is willing to accept the handbill. (Code 1977, § 31-121(9)(c)) Cross reference— Traffic and vehicles, ch. 58. Sec. 46-93. - Clean up. It shall be the responsibility of any person distributing handbills to maintain the area which they are utilizing free of any litter caused by or related to such handbill distribution. (Code 1977, § 31-121(9)(d))

div.head: Chapter 50 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND PUBLIC PLACES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Any ordinance dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, widening, paving, etc., any street or public way in the city saved from repeal, § 1-4(6); any ordinance providing for local improvements and assessing taxes for such improvements saved from repeal, § 1-4(9); any ordinance establishing or prescribing street grades in the city saved from repeal, § 1-4(15); buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; environment, ch. 26; noise control on hawkers, peddlers and vendors, § 26-187; floods, ch. 30; urination, defecation in public, § 38-46; loitering in public places, § 38-91; parks and recreation, ch. 42; storing of refuse in public places, § 46-10; scattering of refuse onto public property, § 46-12; litter control on sidewalks and alleys, § 46-60; placing handbills in public places, § 46-89; traffic and vehicles, ch. 58; maximum speed limits on specific streets, § 58-37; utilities, ch. 62; development regulations, app. A; zoning ordinance, app. B. State Law reference— Governmental authorization for construction or maintenance of any private road unlawful, O.C.G.A. § 32-1-8; state, county and municipal road systems, O.C.G.A. § 32-4-1 et seq.; powers with respect to municipal street system, O.C.G.A. § 32-4-92; regulation of maintenance and use of public roads generally, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-1 et seq.; power of city to open, close or extend public streets, alleys and sidewalks, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-3; power to construct and maintain roads, including curbs, sidewalks, street lights and devices to control the flow of traffic, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(4).
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 50-1. - Supervision generally. All maintenance and repair of public streets, alley, curbs, sidewalks and other public ways shall be under the supervision of the director of public works, who shall have the responsibility of enforcing all provisions of this chapter and all ordinances of the city relating to such public ways. (Code 1977, § 21-101(1)) Sec. 50-2. - General specifications. The specifications for the construction, improvement and maintenance of streets and other public ways in the city shall be as approved by the mayor and city council from time to time and on file in the office of the director of public works. Any variance of such specifications must be approved by the director of public works. It shall be unlawful for any person to construct or lay any pavement for or on any public way or to repair the same without having first obtained a permit from the director of public works. (Code 1977, § 21-105) Sec. 50-3. - Responsibility of owner of abutting property. (a) It shall be the duty of all owners of property in the city upon which sidewalks have been laid to keep such walkways and the land between such walkways and the street in good repair at all times. (b) Property owners with habitable structures shall maintain grass, weeds and growths in the rights-of-way in accordance with section 17.2(B) of the city property maintenance ordinance (section 17.2B of appendix B to this Code). (Code 1977, § 21-101(2)) Sec. 50-4. - Defacing, obstructing sidewalks. It shall be unlawful for any person to deface or obstruct a sidewalk in any manner, or to deposit any waste or objectionable material on a sidewalk, or to use a sidewalk for any private use, such as advertising. (Code 1977, § 21-101(3)) Sec. 50-5. - Maintenance of poles, wires. Any person who lawfully maintains poles or wires adjacent to the streets or other public places of the city shall keep such poles and wires in good repair and free from grass, shrubs or tree limbs. (Code 1977, § 21-101(3)) Cross reference— Utilities, ch. 62. Sec. 50-6. - Certain vehicular traffic prohibited. (a) All steel track vehicles are prohibited on paved streets in the city. (b) All vehicles with a gross weight over 20,000 pounds are prohibited on paved streets in the city. (c) Operators of such vehicles as set forth in subsections (a) and (b) of this section, may, however, request a permit from the police department allowing such person to use the city's streets after posting a surety bond to protect the city against possible damage from such vehicles to such streets. (Code 1977, § 21-104) Cross reference— Traffic and vehicles, ch. 58. Secs. 50-7—50-40. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - EXCAVATIONS
Sec. 50-41. - Permit required. Unless an excavation permit shall first have been obtained from the director of public works, it shall be unlawful for any person to dig up, break, excavate, tunnel, undermine or in any manner break up any street in the city; or to make or cause to be made any excavation in or under the surface of any street for any purpose; or to place, deposit or leave upon any street any earth or other excavated material obstructing or tending to interfere with the free use of the street. (Code 1977, § 21-103(1)) Sec. 50-42. - Bond. Each applicant for a permit under this article shall be required to file a suitable cash bond, in an amount as required by the director of public works, conditioned to indemnify the city for any loss or damage. Such bond will be retained for a minimum of 30 days after repairs are completed. (Code 1977, § 21-103(2)) Sec. 50-43. - Protection of the public. The permittee under this article shall take appropriate measures to ensure that during the performance of excavation work traffic conditions shall be maintained at all times as nearly as practicable so as to cause as little inconvenience and danger as possible to the public. Work shall proceed so that one lane of traffic shall remain open unless the police department or the director of public works orders the street to be closed. At twilight there shall be placed upon each place of excavation, and upon any excavated materials, structures or other obstructions to streets, suitable and sufficient lights which shall be kept burning throughout the night for the duration of such obstruction. (Code 1977, § 21-103(3)) Sec. 50-44. - Backfilling. Along with the permit as set forth in this article, a detail sheet showing proper replacement of backfill and pavement will be issued. The director of public works is to be notified before any excavation is backfilled and any paving is replaced. (Code 1977, § 21-103(4)) Sec. 50-45. - Restoration of surface. (a) The surface of all streets or sidewalks broken into or damaged as a result of excavation work shall be permanently restored by the permittee in strict accordance with the specifications prescribed by the director of public works. The permittee may be required to place a temporary surface over openings made in paved traffic lanes and shall be required to exercise special care in making and maintaining such temporary restorations to ensure safe traveling conditions until such time as permanent restorations are made. (b) If the permittee fails to promptly restore the surface of the street in accordance with the specifications of the director of public works, the director of public works, if he deems it advisable, shall have the right to do all work and anything which is necessary to restore the street. The permittee shall be liable for the actual cost of such restoration and shall pay an additional 25 percent of such cost for general overhead and administrative expenses. Acceptance or approval of any excavation work by the director of public works shall not prevent the city from asserting a claim against the permittee for incomplete or defective work if such incomplete or defective work is discovered within 24 months from the completion of such excavation work. (Code 1977, § 21-103(5), (6)) Sec. 50-46. - Emergency work. If any emergency in which a sewer, main, conduit or utility in or under any street breaks, bursts or otherwise is in such a condition as to immediately endanger the property, life, health or safety of any individual, the person owning or controlling such sewer, main, conduit or utility, without first applying for and obtaining an excavation permit as set forth in this article, shall immediately take proper emergency measures to cure or remedy the dangerous condition for the protection of the property, life, health and safety of individuals. However, such person owning or controlling such sewer, main, conduit or utility shall apply for an excavation permit not later than the end of the next succeeding day during which the office of the director of public works is open for business and shall not proceed with permanent repairs without first obtaining an excavation permit as set forth in this article. (Code 1977, § 21-103(7)) Secs. 50-47—50-80. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - ASSEMBLIES, DEMONSTRATIONS AND PARADES[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Editor's note— Ord. No. 2006-07, Exh. A, adopted Sept. 25, 2006, repealed the former Art. III, §§ 50-81—50-88, and enacted a new Art. III as set out herein. The former Art. III pertained to parades, processions, public demonstrations and derived from Code 1977, § 32-206(A)—(H).
Sec. 50-81. - Purpose. Pursuant to the authority granted to the city by its Charter and the Code of Georgia and its general police powers, the city has adopted the following sections in order to provide for the public health, safety and general welfare in the city, to ensure the free and safe passage of pedestrians and vehicles on the public rights-of-way, and to ensure the safe and unimpaired use and enjoyment of public property in places open to the general public and otherwise to regulate and control the time, place and manner of activities that would otherwise threaten or impair the public health, safety, and welfare in the city while also encouraging the exercise of the rights to free speech and assembly in the city. (Ord. No. 2006-07, Exh. A, 9-25-2006) Sec. 50-82. - Definitions. The following terms shall have the meanings set out herein: Parade means any march, procession or motorcade consisting of 15 or more people, animals, or vehicles, or a combination thereof upon the streets, sidewalks or other public areas within the city that interferes with or has a tendency to interfere with the normal flow or regulation of pedestrian or vehicular traffic upon the streets, sidewalks, or other public property. Public assembly means any meeting, demonstration, picket line, rally or gathering of 15 or more people for a common purpose as a result of prior planning that interferes with or has a tendency to interfere with the normal flow or regulation of pedestrian or vehicular traffic upon the streets, sidewalks, or other public property within the city or that interferes with or has a tendency to interfere with the normal use of any public property in a place open to the general public. Spontaneous event means an unplanned or unannounced coming together of people, animals or vehicles in a parade or public assembly which was not contemplated beforehand by any participant therein and which is caused by or in response to unforeseen circumstances or events occasioned by news or affairs first coming into public knowledge within seven days of such parade or public assembly. (Ord. No. 2006-07, Exh. A, 9-25-2006) Sec. 50-83. - Permit required. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct or participate in a public assembly, demonstration or parade on the public streets, sidewalks, or other public property of the city in a place open to the general public for which a written permit has not been issued in accordance with the provisions of this article. (b) The provisions of this section shall not apply to: (1) Spontaneous events; (2) Recreational activities, including jogging or walking, that do not require closing public streets or other public streets or other public rights-of-way and that do not interfere with or have a tendency to interfere with the normal use of any public property in a place open to the general public; (3) Door-to-door advocacy, including canvassing, pamphleteering, religious or political proselytizing and the distribution of written materials, and similar activities that do not interfere with or have a tendency to interfere with the free passage of pedestrians and vehicles on the public rights-of-way or the normal use of any public property in a place open to the general public; (4) Door-to-door sales of goods or services, and similar activities that do not interfere with or have a tendency to interfere with the free passage of pedestrians and vehicles on the public rights-of-way or the normal use of any public property in a place open to the general public; provided, however, that any persons or organizations engaging in such activities shall comply with any other applicable requirements of this Code; (5) Funeral processions; (6) Students going to and from school classes; (7) The United States Army, Navy, Air Force and Coast Guard, the military forces of the state and the police and fire divisions of the city; (8) Park and recreation areas that are regulated by the city's department of parks, recreation and community facilities. (c) Permits may be granted if they are requested by individuals or organizations who desire to have a permit, even though the permit is not required under this section. (Ord. No. 2006-07, Exh. A, 9-25-2006) Sec. 50-84. - Application. (a) Any person desiring to conduct a parade or public assembly shall make written application to the chief of police, or his designee, at least five days prior to such parade or public assembly. Such application shall set forth the following information: (1) The name, address and telephone number of the person requesting the permit; (2) The name and address of any organization or group the applicant is representing; (3) The name, address and telephone number of the person who will act as the parade or public assembly leader or chairman and who will be responsible for the conduct of the parade or public assembly; (4) The type of public assembly, including a description of the activities planned during the event; (5) The date and time (start and ending) of the parade or public assembly; (6) If an assembly, the specific location or locations of the assembly; (7) If a parade, the specific assembly and dispersal locations, the specific route, and the plans, if any, for assembly and dispersal; (8) The approximate number of people who, and animals and vehicles which will constitute such parade or public assembly and the type of animals and a description of the vehicles; (9) A statement as to whether the parade or public assembly will occupy all or only a portion of the width of the streets or sidewalks or other public rights-of-way proposed to be traversed or used; (10) A description of any recording equipment, sound amplification equipment, banners, signs, or other attention-getting devices to be used in connection with the parade or public assembly; and (11) Such other information as the chief of police, or his designee, may deem reasonably necessary in order to properly provide for traffic control, street and property maintenance, administrative arrangements, police and fire protection, and for the protection of public health, safety and welfare. (b) The chief of police, or his designee, shall not issue the permit if any information supplied by the applicant is false or intentionally misleading. (c) The chief of police, or his designee, shall have the authority to and shall make reasonable efforts to consider an application hereunder which is filed less than five days before the date the parade or assembly is proposed to be conducted if, after due consideration of the date, time, place and nature of the parade or public assembly, the anticipated number of participants and the city services required in connection with the event, and where good cause is otherwise shown, the chief of police, or his designee determines that the waiver of the permit application deadline will not present an undue hazard to public safety. (Ord. No. 2006-07, Exh. A, 9-25-2006) Sec. 50-85. - Issuance or denial of permit. (a) The chief of police, or his designee, shall issue the permit within five days of receipt of the completed application, and in any event prior to the scheduled parade or public assembly, if the proposed parade or public assembly will not endanger the public health, welfare or safety, after applying the following criteria and finding that: (1) The time, duration, route and size of parade or assembly will not unreasonably interrupt the safe and orderly movement of vehicular or pedestrian traffic or the normal use of public property in a place open to the general public; (2) The parade or assembly is not of such a nature that it will require diversion of so great a number of police and fire personnel to properly police the line of movement in the areas contiguous thereto so as to impair the normal protection of the remainder of the city; (3) The applicant has, where appropriate, designated monitors sufficient to control the orderly conduct of the parade or assembly in conformity with such permit; (4) The applicant has, where appropriate, agreed to be responsible for having appropriate traffic control devices installed in accordance with the uniform manual on traffic control devices to close roadways to vehicular traffic sufficient to control the orderly conduct of the parade or assembly in conformity with such permit; (5) The conduct of the parade or assembly will not unduly interfere with the proper fire and police protection of, or ambulance service to, the remainder of the city, or unreasonably disrupt other public services and protection normally provided to the city; (6) The parade or assembly will not interfere with another parade or assembly for which a permit has been granted; and (7) The parade or assembly proposed will not violate, and will conform with all applicable state regulations and laws governing the proposed event. (b) For parades or public assemblies held on a regular or recurring basis at the same location, an application for an annual permit covering all such parades or assemblies during the calendar year may be filed with the chief of police, or his designee, at least five and not more than 30 days before the date and time at which the first such parade or public assembly is proposed to commence. The chief of police, or his designee, may and shall make reasonable efforts to consider an application hereunder which is filed less than five days before the date and time at which the first parade or assembly is proposed to commence, after due consideration of the factors specified in subsection (c) of section 50-83. (c) If the chief of police, or his designee, denies an application, he shall promptly attempt to call and shall promptly mail to the applicant a notice of his action, stating the reasons for his denial of the permit and notifying the applicant of his right to appeal the denial pursuant to section 50-89 of this article. (d) If two or more applications are submitted requesting a permit under this article for a parade or assembly to be used at the same time and place, the application first filed shall be granted if it meets the requirements of this article; (e) Nothing in this article shall permit the chief of police, or his designee, to deny a permit based upon political, social or religious grounds or reasons or based upon the content of the views expressed. Denial of a permit on such grounds is prohibited. (f) Under no circumstances shall more than one permit be issued under this article to the same person or organization in any three-month period. (Ord. No. 2006-07, Exh. A, 9-25-2006; Ord. No. 2008-10, § 1, 4-28-2008) Sec. 50-86. - Alternative permit. The chief of police, or his designee, in denying a permit for a parade or public assembly shall be empowered to authorize the conduct of the parade or assembly on a date, at a time, at a place, or over a route different from that proposed by the applicant. An applicant desiring to accept an alternate permit shall file a written notice of acceptance with the chief of police, or his designee. An alternate permit shall conform to the requirements of and shall have the effect of a permit under this article. (Ord. No. 2006-07, Exh. A, 9-25-2006) Sec. 50-87. - Compliance with directions and conditions. Every person to whom a permit is issued under this article shall substantially comply with all permit terms and conditions and with all applicable laws and ordinances. The parade or assembly chairman or other person heading or leading the parade or assembly shall carry the permit upon his person during the conduct of the parade or assembly and show the permit when requested to do so. (Ord. No. 2006-07, Exh. A, 9-25-2006) Sec. 50-88. - Revocation of permit. The chief of police, or his designee, shall have the authority to revoke any permit issued pursuant to this article if any information supplied by the applicant is discovered to be false or intentionally misleading, if any term, condition, restriction or limitation of the permit has been substantially violated or if there is any continued violation of the terms, conditions, restrictions or limitations of the permit after the applicant or anyone acting in concert with him is notified of a violation of the permit by an appropriate law enforcement official. (Ord. No. 2006-07, Exh. A, 9-25-2006) Sec. 50-89. - Appeal. (a) Any person aggrieved by the refusal of the chief of police or his designee to grant a permit or by the revocation of a permit after one has been issued, shall appeal the denial by filing with the city manager's office, within five working days after the date of denial or revocation, a written notice of the appeal setting for the grounds therefor. The city manager shall act upon the appeal within 48 hours after its receipt. (b) The decision of the city manager in under subsection (a), may be appealed to the Superior Court of Gwinnett County in accordance with state law. (c) In any appeal under this section, the city shall have the burden of demonstrating that the denial of the permit was justified under section 50-85 of this article. (d) The city shall meet all deadlines set by the court and by applicable statutes and court rules, and shall otherwise seek to assure that the appeal, including any motion for preliminary relief, is decided as expeditiously as possible. (Ord. No. 2006-07, Exh. A, 9-25-2006; Ord. No. 2008-10, § 2, 4-28-2008) Sec. 50-90. - Public conduct during parades, demonstrations and assemblies. (a) Interference. No person shall unreasonably hamper, obstruct, impede or interfere with any parade, demonstration or assembly or with any person, vehicle or animal participating or used in a parade, demonstration or assembly for which a written permit has been issued in accordance with the provisions of this article. (b) Driving through parades. No driver of a vehicle shall drive between the vehicles, persons or animals comprising a parade, demonstration or assembly except when otherwise directed by a police officer. This shall not apply to authorized emergency vehicles such as fire apparatus, ambulances and police vehicles. (c) Parking on parade, demonstration or assembly route. The chief of police, or his designee, shall have the authority, when reasonably necessary, to prohibit or restrict the parking of vehicles along the public streets or public rights-of-way constituting a part of the route of a parade, demonstration or assembly. The chief of police, or his designee, shall ensure that signs are posted to such effect, and it shall be unlawful for any person to park or leave unattended any vehicle in violation thereof. No person shall be liable for parking on a street unposted in violation of this article. (Ord. No. 2006-07, Exh. A, 9-25-2006)

div.head: Chapter 54 - TAXATION[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Any ordinance providing for local improvements and assessing taxes for such improvements saved from repeal, § 1-4(9); any ordinance levying or imposing taxes not included in this Code saved from repeal, § 1-4(14); administration, ch. 2; businesses, ch. 22. State Law reference— Limitation on taxing power of municipalities and counties, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ VIII; taxation power of municipal and county governments, Ga. Const. art. IX, § IV, ¶ I.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 54-1. - Public utility franchise tax. (a) Rate of levy. There is set and levied on all businesses granted a franchise by the city a franchise tax in the amount of three percent of the gross revenue per quarter received from residential, commercial and industrial sales. (b) Due date and required report. The franchise tax shall be paid on April 1, July 1, October 1 and January 1 of each year. Payment shall be accompanied by a report showing the volume of gross sales by service classification (residential, commercial or industrial) for the preceding quarter. When payment is more than ten days late, an additional fee of one percent of quarterly gross income shall be assessed. (Code 1977, § 4-104) Cross reference— Utilities, ch. 62. Secs. 54-2—54-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - AD VALOREM TAXES[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Ad valorem taxation of property, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-1 et seq.; municipal ad valorem taxation, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-350 et seq.
Sec. 54-31. - Rate of levy. The mayor and city council shall annually set and levy an ad valorem tax to meet the ordinary and current expenses of the city upon all real and personal property within the city. (Code 1977, § 4-101(1); Ord. of 2-15-1999) Sec. 54-32. - Assessment and fair market value. All property subject to municipal ad valorem taxation shall be assessed at 40 percent of its fair market value. The basis for fair market value shall be 100 percent of the fair market value determined for the property by the county for county ad valorem tax purposes. (Code 1977, § 4-101(2); Ord. of 2-15-1999) Sec. 54-33. - Appeal of assessment. Any taxpayer may appeal from an assessment by the county board of tax assessors to the county board of equalization as to matters of taxability, uniformity of assessment, and value, and the taxpayer of the county board of tax assessors may appeal to the superior court of the county in which the property lies from a decision of the county board of equalization. All such other appeals shall be made in the manner provided by state law. (Code 1977, § 4-101(3); Ord. of 2-15-1999) Sec. 54-34. - When taxes due and payable. Tax bills showing the assessed valuations, amount of taxes due, tax due dates and information as to the delinquency dates and penalties shall be sent to all taxpayers at least 30 days prior to the due date, but failure to send a tax bill shall not invalidate any tax. Taxes of all kinds owed to the city, including, but not limited to, malt beverage and wine excise taxes, shall bear interest at the rate established by law, per month, from the date the tax is due until the tax is paid. For the purposes of this section, any period of less than one month shall be considered to be one month. (Code 1977, § 4-101(4); Ord. of 2-15-1999) Sec. 54-35. - Failure to pay tax. The billing entity shall forthwith issue an execution against any person who has defaulted in the payment of any ad valorem tax. The execution so issued shall be a lien on all of the property of such person, both real and personal, and shall be placed in the hands of the officer responsible for collection by levy and sale. (Code 1977, § 4-101(5); Ord. of 2-15-1999) Sec. 54-36. - Against whom charged. Taxes are to be charged against the owner of the property, if known, or against the specific property itself if the owner is not known. Life tenants and those who enjoy the use of the taxed property are chargeable with the tax on such property. (Code 1977, § 4-101(6); Ord. of 2-15-1999) Sec. 54-37. - Exempt property. The following property shall be exempt from ad valorem taxation: (1) All public property; (2) All places of religious worship and places of burial; and (3) All buildings used as a college, university or other seminary of learning. (Code 1977, § 4-101(7); Ord. of 2-15-1999) Sec. 54-38. - Homestead exemption. (a) The owner of a homestead which is actually occupied by the owner as a residence and homestead as of January 1 may take advantage of the $3,000.00 homestead exemption from ad valorem taxation by filing an application for exemption between January 1 and May 1 of the year for which the exemption is first claimed by the taxpayer. (b) Every resident who is 65 years of age or older, or who is totally disabled, may take advantage of the $5,000.00 homestead exemption from ad valorem taxation by filing an application for exemption between January 1 and May 1 of the year for which the exemption is first claimed by the taxpayer. (c) Once granted, the homestead exemption is automatically renewed each year unless there is a change in ownership, name or spelling correction on the deed, or if the taxpayer seeks to qualify for a different type of exemption. (Code 1977, § 4-101(8); Ord. of 2-15-1999) Sec. 54-39. - Failure to pay; penalty. For failure to pay an ad valorem tax, to the extent allowed by state law (O.C.G.A. § 48-2-44), a penalty of ten percent shall be added to such tax. (Code 1977, § 4-101(9); Ord. of 2-15-1999) Secs. 54-40—54-70. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS[3]
Footnotes: --- (3) --- State Law reference— Local depository financial institutions business license tax, O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93.
Sec. 54-71. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Gross receipts has the same meaning as is ascribed to such term in O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93 for each such depository financial institution. (Ord. of 9-11-1995, § 32-205(B)) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 54-72. - Calculation of gross receipts. (a) Gross receipts shall be the total amount of revenue generated from the sources itemized in subsections (b) and (c) of this section during the calendar year immediately preceding the date on which the tax authorized by this article shall be due. Before determining gross receipts, there shall be deducted: (1) An amount equal to the amount of interest paid on all liabilities for the period; (2) An amount equal to income derived from the authorized activities of any domestic international banking facility operating pursuant to the Domestic International Banking Facility Act, O.C.G.A. § 7-1-730 et seq.; (3) An amount equal to any income arising from the conduct of a banking business with persons or entities located outside of the United States, its territories or possessions; (4) An amount equal to a depository financial institution's gross income which is taxed under the tax laws of a state other than Georgia; and (5) The extent that any deductions are made pursuant to subsections (a)(2)—(4) of this section, any deductions taken under subsection (a)(1) of this section shall be reduced by the same proportion that the deductions in subsections (a)(2)—(4) of this section bear to the gross receipts of the depository financial institution as calculated before making any deductions pursuant to subsections (a)(1)—(4) of this section. (b) With respect to banks, the items to be included in the calculation of gross receipts are as follows: (1) Interest and fees on loans less any interest collected on such portions of loans sold and serviced for others; (2) Interest on balances with other depository financial institutions; (3) Interest on federal or correspondent funds sold and securities purchased under an agreement to resell; (4) Interest on other bonds, notes and debentures, excluding interest on obligations of the state or its political subdivisions and obligations of the United States; (5) Dividends on stock; (6) Income from direct lease financing; (7) Income from fiduciary activities; (8) Service charges on deposit accounts; (9) Other service charges, commissions and fees; and (10) Other income. (c) With respect to savings and loan associations, the items to be included in the calculation of gross receipts are as follows: (1) Interest on mortgage loans less any interest collected on those portions of loans sold and serviced for others; (2) Interest on mortgages, participations or mortgage-backed securities; (3) Interest on real estate sold on contract; (4) Discounts on mortgage loans purchased; (5) Interest on other loans, excluding interest on obligations of the state or its political subdivisions and obligations of the United States; (6) Interest and dividends on investments and deposits; (7) Loan fees; (8) Loan servicing fees; (9) Other fees and charges; (10) Gross income from real estate owned operations; (11) Net income from office building operations; (12) Gross income from real estate held for investment; (13) Net income from service corporations and subsidiaries; (14) Miscellaneous operating income; (15) Profit on the sale of real estate owned, investment securities, loans and other assets; and (16) Miscellaneous nonoperating income. (Ord. of 9-11-1995, § 32-205(B)) Sec. 54-73. - Tax levied. Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93, there is levied an annual business license tax upon depository financial institutions located within the city at the rate of 0.25 percent of the gross receipts of such depository financial institutions. The minimum annual amount of such levy upon any depository financial institution shall be as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk. (Ord. of 9-11-1995, § 32-205(A)) Sec. 54-74. - Filing of return. Each depository financial institution subject to the tax levied in section 54-73 shall file with the city not later than March 1 of each year a return of such depository financial institution's gross receipts received by such depository financial institution during the immediately preceding calendar year. The return shall be made in the manner and form prescribed by the commissioner of the department of banking and shall be based on the allocation method set forth in O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93(d). The tax levied pursuant to this article shall be assessed and collected based upon the information provided in the return. (Ord. of 9-11-1995, § 32-205(C)) Sec. 54-75. - Allocation of gross receipts. The total gross receipts generated in this state by a depositor's financial institution subject to any tax authorized by this article shall be allocated among separate taxing jurisdictions as follows: (1) If a depository financial institution shall have an office or a place of business in more than one municipality, the amount of gross receipts taxable by each municipality shall be the amount of gross receipts attributable to such offices or places of business as of December 31 of the year in which such gross receipts are measured; (2) If a depository financial institution shall have an office or a place of business in more than one county, the amount of gross receipts taxable by each county shall be the amount of gross receipts attributable to such offices or places of business as of December 31 of the year in which gross receipts are measured; and (3) In determining the amount of gross receipts attributable to each location, 20 percent of the gross receipts shall be attributable to the parent bank. The remaining 80 percent of gross receipts shall be attributable to branch banks and bank offices, with none of the gross receipts attributable to bank facilities or other outlets not considered to be a parent bank, branch bank or bank office. The term "parent bank," "branch bank" and "bank office," as used in this section, shall have the same meaning as such terms are defined in the Financial Institutions Code of Georgia (O.C.G.A. § 7-1-1 et seq.). If there are fewer than five branch banks or bank offices in addition to the parent bank, the amount of gross receipts attributable to each such parent bank, branch bank or bank office shall be determined by dividing the total gross receipts by the aggregate number of such outlets. For purposes of the distribution formula only, the term "bank" also means a savings and loan association. (Ord. of 9-11-1995, § 32-205(D)) Sec. 54-76. - Tax credit. Any tax paid by a depository financial institution pursuant to this article and O.C.G.A. § 48-6-95 shall be credited dollar for dollar against any state corporate income tax liability of such depository financial institution for the tax year during which any business and occupation tax authorized by this article is paid. Such credit shall be subject to the provisions contained in O.C.G.A. § 48-7-21(B)(1). (Ord. of 9-11-1995, § 32-205(E)) Secs. 54-77—54-110. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - INSURERS[4]
Footnotes: --- (4) --- State Law reference— Local tax on life insurance companies, O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.1; local tax on other than life insurance companies, O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.2.
Sec. 54-111. - License fee levied for insurance companies engaging in the business of insurance; additional locations generally. There is levied an annual license fee as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk upon every insurance company engaging in the business of insurance within the corporate limits of the city. There is levied an additional annual license fee in such amount as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk for each separate business location in excess of one operated and maintained by any such company within the corporate limits of the city. (Ord. of 9-11-1995, § 32-202(A)) State Law reference— Local tax on life insurance companies, O.C.G.A. § 38-8-8.1. Sec. 54-112. - License fee levied for businesses lending money or offering term financing of sales; taking insurance applications. There is levied an additional license fee as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk on each insurance company for each separate business location not otherwise subject to a license fee under section 54-111, which company is operated and maintained by a business organization which is engaged in the business of lending money or transacting sales involving term financing and which, in connection with the loans or sales involving term financing, offers, solicits or takes applications for insurance through a licensed agent of the insurance company for insurance. (Ord. of 9-11-1995, § 32-202(B)) State Law reference— Local tax on other than life insurance companies, O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.2. Sec. 54-113. - License fee levied for additional locations of independent agencies and brokers. There is levied an annual license fee upon independent agencies and brokers for each separate business location from which a life insurance business is conducted and which is not subject to the company license fee imposed by either section 54-111 or section 54-112 in the amount set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk for each such location within the city. (Ord. of 9-11-1995, § 32-202(C)) Sec. 54-114. - Gross direct premiums tax levied. There is levied an annual tax based solely upon gross direct premiums upon each insurer writing life, accident and sickness insurance within the city in an amount equal to one percent of the gross direct premiums received during the calendar year in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.1. The term "gross direct premiums," as used in this section, shall mean gross direct premiums as used in O.C.G.A. § 33-8-4. The premium tax levied by this section is in addition to the license fees imposed by sections 54-111 and 54-112. (Ord. of 9-11-1995, § 32-202(D)) Sec. 54-115. - Gross direct premiums tax levied on classes of insurance other than life, accident and sickness. There is levied an annual tax upon each insurer, other than an insurer transacting business in the class of insurance designated in O.C.G.A. § 33-3-5(1), doing business as provided in O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.2 in an amount equal to 2½ percent of the gross direct premiums received during the calendar year in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.2. The term "gross direct premiums," as used in this section, means gross direct premiums as used in O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.2(a). (Ord. of 9-11-1995, § 33-202(E)) Sec. 54-116. - Due date for license fees. License fees imposed in this article shall be due and payable January 1 of each year. (Ord. of 9-11-1995, § 32-202(F)) Secs. 54-117—54-150. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - OCCUPATION TAXES[5]
Footnotes: --- (5) --- Editor's note— Ord. No. 2004-05, adopted Jan. 10, 2005, amended art. V of this chapter in its entirety. Prior to amendment, art. V, §§ 54-151—54-177, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from an ordinance adopted Jan. 23, 1995, §§ 32-101—32-122, 32-124; an ordinance adopted Sept. 11, 1995; and an ordinance adopted Aug. 14, 2000. Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 22. State Law reference— Business and occupation taxes, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-1 et seq.
Sec. 54-151. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Administrative fee means the component of an occupation tax which approximates the reasonable cost of handling and processing the registration of the business from whom the occupation tax is collected. Dominant line means the type of business within a multiple service or product business from which the greatest amount of revenue is derived. Gross receipts means the total revenue of the business or practitioner for the period, including, but not limited to the following: (1) Total income without deduction for the cost of goods or expenses incurred; (2) Gain from trading in stocks, bonds, capital assets or instruments of indebtedness; (3) Proceeds from commission on the sale of property, goods or services; (4) Proceeds from rent, interest, royalty or dividend income. Gross receipts shall not include the following: (1) Sales, use or excise tax; (2) Sales returns, allowances and discounts; (3) Interorganizational sales or transfers between or among the units of a parent-subsidiary controlled group of corporations as defined in 26 USC § 1563(a)(1), or between or among the units of a brother-sister controlled group of corporations as defined in 26 USC § 1563(a)(2), or between or among wholly-owned partnerships or other wholly-owned entities; (4) Payments made to a subcontractor or an independent agent; (5) Governmental and foundation grants, charitable contributions or the interest income derived from such funds received by a nonprofit organization which employs salaried practitioners otherwise covered by this article; and (6) Proceeds from sales to customers outside of the state. Location and office mean any structure or vehicle where a business, profession or occupation is conducted, but shall not include a temporary or construction work site which serves a single customer or project or a vehicle used for sales or delivery by a business or practitioner of a profession. Occupation tax means a tax levied on persons, partnerships, corporations or other entities for engaging in an occupation, profession or business for revenue purposes. Occupation tax certificate means a document issued by the city acknowledging payment of the occupation tax and administrative fee. Person includes sole proprietors, practitioners of professions, corporations, partnerships, or any other form of organization. Practitioners of professions means and includes: (1) Lawyers; (2) Physicians licensed under O.C.G.A. § 43-34-20 et seq.; (3) Osteopaths licensed under O.C.G.A. § 43-34-20 et seq.; (4) Chiropractors; (5) Podiatrists; (6) Dentists; (7) Optometrists; (8) Psychologists; (9) Veterinarians; (10) Landscape architects; (11) Land surveyors; (12) Practitioners of physiotherapy; (13) Public accountants; (14) Embalmers; (15) Funeral directors; (16) Civil, mechanical, hydraulic or electrical engineers; (17) Architects; and (18) Marriage and family therapists, social workers and professional counselors. Such term shall not include a practitioner who is an employee of a business if the business pays an occupation tax. Profitability class means the category into which an occupation is placed for occupation tax purposes. Regulatory fee means the payment required by the city as an exercise of its police power as part of or as an aid to regulation of an occupation, profession or business, the amount of which shall approximate the reasonable cost of the actual regulatory activity performed by the city. Regulatory fee certificate means a document issued by the city acknowledging payment of the regulatory fee. Standard industrial classification means categories of occupations and industries established and promulgated by the Office of Management and Budget of the United States of America and found in the Standard Industrial Classification Manual of 1987. (Ord. No. 2004-05, 1-10-2005; Ord. No. 2010-10, § 1, 5-24-2010) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 54-152. - Tax levied. (a) An occupation tax is levied upon those persons with one or more locations or offices within the corporate limits of the city and, pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-7, upon out-of-state persons with no location or office in the state in accordance with the occupation tax schedule on file in the office of the city clerk. (b) A person shall be placed in the profitability class based on the dominant line of business or service of the person, and profitability ratios as measured by nationwide averages derived from statistics, classifications or other information published by the U.S. Office of Management and Budget, the U.S. Internal Revenue Service or successor agencies of the United States shall be used to classify the dominant line of business by tax class. Profitability classes by standard industrial classification (SIC) code shall be listed in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk. (c) Persons with no physical location in the state, but who perform services or sell products within the corporate limits of the city, shall be subject to the administrative fee and occupation tax if such person has more than nominal business activity within the city, including: (1) One or more employees who exert effort within the jurisdiction of the city for the purpose of soliciting business or serving customers or clients; or (2) Ownership of real or personal property which is located within the jurisdiction of the city and which generates income or is used to generate income. (Ord. No. 2004-05, 1-10-2005) Sec. 54-153. - Required. Any person practicing a profession, occupation or business without having valid certificates issued under this article shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 54-180. (Ord. No. 2004-05, 1-10-2005) Sec. 54-154. - Exemptions. (a) No occupation tax shall be levied upon the following: (1) Any practitioner whose office is maintained by and who is employed in practice exclusively by the United States, the state, a municipality or county of the state or instrumentality of the United States, the state or a municipality or county of the state; (2) Those businesses regulated by the state public service commission; (3) Those electrical service businesses organized under O.C.G.A. § 46-3-1 et seq.; (4) Any farm operation for the production from or on the land of agricultural products, but not including any agricultural business; (5) Nonprofit agricultural product cooperative marketing associations pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 2-10-105; (6) Motor common carriers pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 46-7-15; (7) Persons purchasing guano, meats, meal, flour, bran, cotton seed or cotton seed meal or hulls in carload lots for distribution among the purchasers for use and not sale pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-5-355; (8) Persons selling or introducing into the city agricultural products or livestock, including animal products, raised in the state when the sale and introduction are made by the producer of such product and the sale is made within 90 days of the introduction of the product into the city; (9) Depository institutions pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93; or (10) Any business where the levy of such occupation tax is prohibited by the laws of the state or of the United States. (b) The exemptions and limitations set forth in subsection (a) of this section shall not be construed to repeal or otherwise affect, in any way, franchise fees, business taxes or other fees or taxes otherwise permitted by law. (Ord. No. 2004-05, 1-10-2005) Sec. 54-155. - When due; issuing of certificate. Any administrative fee, regulatory fee or occupation tax shall be payable January 1 of each year and shall be delinquent if not paid by April 1 of each year. Any amounts owed which are not paid by April 1 shall be subject to the penalties for delinquency as set forth in section 54-175. For any new profession, occupation or business begun in the city after January 1 of any year, the administrative fee, regulatory fee and occupation tax, as applicable, shall be obtained immediately upon beginning business, and if not so obtained, shall be delinquent. A regulatory fee certificate and an occupation tax certificate indicating that the profession, occupation or business has paid the fees and taxes owed shall be issued by the planning department. (Ord. No. 2004-05, 1-10-2005) Sec. 54-156. - Attorneys. (a) Notwithstanding any language to the contrary elsewhere in this article, an attorney shall not be required to pay the occupation tax on the income generated from the practice of law in any calendar year beginning with and including the year 2004 until April 1 of the year following. An attorney who pays the occupation tax on their own behalf shall include the name of the law firm with which they practice, if any. Any tax paid pursuant to occupation tax on gross receipts shall include a written submission containing sufficient information to enable city staff to determine the accuracy of the taxpayer's calculation. (b) Taxes due from attorneys shall not be considered delinquent until June 1. An attorney who does not pay the tax prior to June 1 shall incur a penalty and accrue interest in accordance with section 54-175. (Ord. No. 2004-05, 1-10-2005; Ord. No. 2011-06, pt. 1, 5-9-2011) Sec. 54-157. - Regulatory fee. (a) Imposed. An annual regulatory fee as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk is imposed on persons engaged in the businesses listed in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9(b)(1-31). (b) Proration. If a person engages in an activity regulated by the city on or after July 1 in any year, the regulatory fee for the remaining portion of the year shall be 50 percent of the regulatory fee for the entire year. (c) Display of certificate. Every person subject to payment of a regulatory fee levied by this section shall display a current regulatory fee certificate in a conspicuous place at the location for which such certificate was issued. If a taxpayer does not have a permanent location within the city, the regulatory fee certificate shall be shown to any police officer and/or the director of planning and development or his/her designee upon request. (Ord. No. 2004-05, 1-10-2005; Ord. No. 2011-06, pt. 2, 5-9-2011) Sec. 54-158. - Limitations. (a) The city shall not require the payment of more than one occupation tax for each location of a person. (1) If a person with no location or office in the city provides to the city proof of payment of a local business or occupation tax in another state which purports to tax the person's gross receipts in this state, then the person shall be exempt from the occupation tax levied by this article. (2) A person who has locations or offices elsewhere in this state who is subject to an occupation tax by more than one local government in this state shall be subject to an occupation tax by the city, unless the person provides documentation to the city of current payment of an occupation tax, measured by the gross receipts of the person, to the other local governments in the state. (b) Persons from out-of-state with no office or location in this state subject to an occupation tax under this article shall be required to pay an occupation tax to only one local government in this state. Such local government shall be the government of the municipal corporation or county in which the largest dollar volume of business is done or services are performed by the person. Such person submitting documentation to the city showing payment of a local business or occupation tax to another local government in this state shall be exempt from the occupation tax levied by this article. (c) No occupation tax will be required upon more than 100 percent of a business' gross receipts. (d) No occupation tax will be required on receipts on which such tax has been levied in other localities or states. (e) An occupation tax shall not be levied in any other manner except as set forth in this section. (f) Out-of-state businesses with no location in this state shall be assessed occupation taxes based on the gross receipts of the business as defined in O.C.G.A. § 14-13-7 which are reasonably attributed to sales or services in the state. (Ord. No. 2004-05, 1-10-2005) Sec. 54-159. - Proration. If a person commences business in the city on or after July 1 of any year, the occupation tax for the remaining portion of the year shall be 50 percent of the tax imposed for the entire year. The administrative fee shall not be reduced. (Ord. No. 2004-05, 1-10-2005) Sec. 54-160. - Registration of line of business. The registration by each person under this article shall identify the dominant line of business, profession or occupation conducted by such person. (Ord. No. 2004-05, 1-10-2005) Sec. 54-161. - Separate businesses at separate locations. Whenever a business or occupation is conducted at more than one location or place within the city, each such location or place shall be considered a separate business for the purpose of the occupation tax imposed by this article. (Ord. No. 2004-05, 1-10-2005) Sec. 54-162. - Allocation of gross receipts at different locations. (a) For those businesses that have multiple locations inside and outside of the city where the gross receipts can be allocated to each location, the gross receipts used to determine the occupation tax assessed will be those gross receipts generated by each city location. Where the dollar amount of gross receipts cannot be allocated among multiple locations, the total gross receipts will be divided by the total number of locations in the city and elsewhere, and an equal percentage of such gross receipts shall be allotted to each location. Upon request, the business or practitioner with a location or office situated in more than one jurisdiction shall provide the following to the city: (1) Financial information necessary to allocate the gross receipts of the business or practitioner; and (2) Information relating to the allocation of the business' or practitioner's gross receipts by other local governments. (b) Where the business has locations outside of the city and taxation is levied for a criteria other than gross receipts in the other local governments, the city shall not assess more than the allotted share of gross receipts for the local operation. (Ord. No. 2004-05, 1-10-2005) Sec. 54-163. - Professionals. (a) Practitioners of professions shall elect for their occupation tax either: (1) The occupation tax as set forth in section 54-152; or (2) A tax, as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk, for each practitioner who is licensed to provide the service, which tax shall be paid at the practitioner's office or location. (b) The election of an occupation tax shall be made on or before March 1 of each calendar year. Such election shall be changed for subsequent calendar years only by a written request filed by the professional on or before March 1 of the year in which the election is to be changed. (Ord. No. 2004-05, 1-10-2005) Sec. 54-164. - Real estate brokers. Real estate brokers shall be subject to the occupation tax imposed by this article only if such real estate brokers maintain a principal or branch office in the city. (Ord. No. 2004-05, 1-10-2005; Ord. No. 2011-15, 7-25-2011) Sec. 54-165. - Display of certificate. Every person subject to payment of the occupation tax set forth in this article shall display a current occupation tax certificate in a conspicuous place at the location for which such certificate was issued. If the taxpayer does not have a permanent location within the city, the occupation tax certificate shall be shown to any police officer and/or the director of planning and development or his/her designee upon request. (Ord. No. 2004-05, 1-10-2005) Sec. 54-166. - Duration. Each administrative fee, regulatory fee and occupation tax, as applicable, required by this article shall be for the calendar year. (Ord. No. 2004-05, 1-10-2005) Sec. 54-167. - Filing of gross receipts. (a) All occupation taxes levied under this article are levied on the amount of business to be transacted during the current calendar year. However, for convenience of both the city and the taxpayer, each business subject to the occupation tax shall, on or before the dates set forth in this article, file with the city the return specifically provided for in this article, showing the gross receipts of that business during the preceding calendar year. This return shall be used as the basis for making payments on the occupation tax for the current calendar year. (b) The person subject to such occupation tax of the current calendar year shall, at the end of the preceding year, and on or before April 1 of the current calendar year, file with the city, on a form furnished by the city, a signed return setting forth the amount of gross receipts of such business for the entire preceding calendar year. Such return will be used to determine the final tax for the calendar year just completed and as an estimate of the gross receipts and occupation tax for the current calendar year. (c) Where a business subject to the occupation tax for the calendar year has been conducted for only a part of the preceding year, the amount of gross receipts for such part of a year shall be reported in the return. Such return shall also show a figure putting the receipts for such part of a year on an annual basis with the part year receipts bearing the same ratio to the whole year gross receipts as the part year bears to the whole year. Such figure shall be used as the estimate of the gross receipts of the business for the current calendar year in establishing the business tax liability. (Ord. No. 2004-05, 1-10-2005) Sec. 54-168. - Reserved. Editor's note— Ord. No. 2009-01, § 1, adopted Feb. 23, 2009, amended by deleting § 54-168, which pertained to conditional use permits and derived from Ord. No. 2007-05, § 1, adopted Oct. 22, 2007. Sec. 54-169. - Confidentiality. Information provided by a person to the city for the purpose of determining the applicability and the amount of the occupation tax or the levy or collection of the occupation tax levied pursuant to this article is confidential and exempt from disclosure. Such information may be provided to the governing authority of another local government for occupation tax purposes or pursuant to court order or for the purpose of collecting occupation tax or prosecution for failure or refusal to pay an occupation tax. (Ord. No. 2004-05, 1-10-2005) Sec. 54-170. - Evidence of state registration; other qualifications. (a) Each person who is licensed under O.C.G.A. tit. 43, by the examining boards of the secretary of state's office shall provide evidence of proper and current state licensure before any city regulatory fee certificate may be issued. (b) Any person required to obtain health permits, bonds, certificates of qualification, certificate of competency or any other regulatory matter shall first, before the issuance of a city registration, show evidence of such qualification. (c) Any person required to submit an annual application for continuance of such business shall do so before the registration is issued. (Ord. No. 2004-05, 1-10-2005) Sec. 54-171. - Residential community sales and canvassing business license. (a) This section is enacted pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 35-3-35 to regulate the issuance of licenses of those engaged in residential community sales and canvassing and to promote the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the City of Snellville. (b) Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: For the purposes of this article: (1) "Solicitation" shall mean the act of going door-to-door or house-to-house in the residentially zoned areas of the city and engaging in any type of stranger-to-stranger conversation, canvassing for information, selling, seeking donations, distributing literature, or performing any other business, occupation or vocation which involves any attempt to obtain money, orders, services, donations, memberships, subscriptions or the like, whether such activity be on a temporary or permanent basis, and whether or not it be for any charitable, nonprofit or profit-making organization or enterprise. (2) "Salesperson" shall mean any person engaging in solicitation. (3) "Solicitation permit" shall mean a photographic identification badge to be issued to authorize solicitors by the Snellville Police Department after approval. (c) Restricted conduct. (1) No salesperson shall enter upon the property of a dwelling posted for no solicitation. Posting for no solicitation shall be made at any residential dwelling or in any group of apartments by placing a conspicuous sign communicating the following instructions: "No Soliciting," "No Solicitation," "No Peddlers," "No Trespassing", or other similar sign displayed at or near the main entrance or driveway of the premises. Homeowners associations can post to prevent solicitation for an entire neighborhood by citing this Code section on their signage at all entrances into the subdivision in the same form and language as outlined above. (2) All salespersons and persons engaged in solicitation shall obtain a permit or be under the supervision of a permitted solicitor in compliance with the requirements of this section. Such persons shall first register with the Snellville Police Department by completing a personal information questionnaire, submitting to a background check, submitting two sets of his/her fingerprints taken by the City of Snellville Police Department and then obtaining a City of Snellville solicitation permit badge and a vehicle solicitation sign to be displayed in any parked vehicle in accordance with the procedure described in this section and on forms approved by the chief of police. Permits issued pursuant to this section shall be valid for 12 months following the date of issuance. (3) Notwithstanding any other provision of the ordinance codified herein, a salesperson or person representing a nonprofit entity registered with the Secretary of State of the State of Georgia or a charitable institution as that term is defined in the Internal Revenue Code or political candidates or those soliciting on behalf of political candidate shall be exempt from the permit requirements of this chapter. (4) Any soliciting person(s) or group of persons 17 years of age or under shall be under the supervision of an adult of 21 years or older. The adult supervisors are required to obtain a solicitation permit for the protection of the children and in compliance with this section. A separate permit is not required for each juvenile solicitor. When juveniles solicit under this provision they must either be in the uniform of the organization they represent or have a badge identifying the adult supervisor and their organization in the form required for other solicitors. Although nonprofits and charitable institutions are not required to be permitted under subsection (c)(3) of this section, such groups are encouraged to meet the requirements of this section voluntarily to insure the safety of the minors soliciting within the city. (d) Application, state and national background check and application fee. (1) The Snellville Police Department, Chief of Police or designee, shall prepare a questionnaire for the purpose of obtaining pertinent information regarding the physical description, identity, and background of each applicant for a permit. The questionnaire shall include the following: a. Name, local address and telephone number; b. Date and place of birth; c. Driver's license number and issuing state or current valid government issued identification with photo; d. Social Security number; e. Height and weight; f. Eye color and hair color; g. Name, address and telephone number of the organization represented; h. Name and telephone number of immediate supervisor; i. Product or service; and j. A list of all arrests, convictions and the disposition of each charge, other than minor traffic violations. A response to any item on the application which indicates that the applicant has violated a prior permit, solicited in any city without a required permit, previously violated the requirements of this section, pled guilty or been convicted of a crime may result in disqualification. (2) The questionnaire form shall also bear the following statement: "O.C.G.A. § 16-10-71, provides that a person who makes a lawful oath or affirmation or who executes a document knowing that it purports to be an acknowledgement of a lawful oath or affirmation commits the offense of false swearing when, in any matter or thing other than a judicial proceeding, he or she knowingly and willfully makes a false statement." (3) Each applicant will also provide two sets of fingerprints taken by the City of Snellville Police Department. Upon receipt of the fingerprints and the appropriate fees, the City of Snellville Police Department will transmit both sets of fingerprints and appropriate fees to the Georgia Bureau of Investigation/GCIC. The Georgia Bureau of Investigation/GCIC will compare the subject's fingerprints against its criminal file and submit the fingerprints to the Federal Bureau of Investigation for a comparison with nation-wide records. The results of the Federal Bureau of Investigation check will be returned to the Georgia Bureau of Investigation/GCIC, which will disseminate the state and national results to the City of Snellville Police Department. (4) In compliance with Public Law 92-544, which provides for the rendering of a fitness determination, the City of Snellville Police Department will render a fitness determination based upon the results of the criminal background check. In rendering a fitness determination, the City of Snellville Police Department will decide whether the record subject has been convicted of (or is under pending indictment for: (a) any felony; or a (b) misdemeanor which involved a crime of moral turpitude, force or threat of force, possession of weapons, controlled substances, or was a sex-related offense; or (c) enumerated disqualifiers set forth in (d)(1) of this section of the Municipal Code of the City of Snellville, Georgia. (5) A record subject may request and receive a copy of his/her criminal history record information from the Snellville Police Department. Should the record subject seek to amend or correct his/her record, he/she must contact the Georgia Bureau of Investigation/GCIC for a Georgia state record or the Federal Bureau of Investigation for records from other jurisdictions maintained in its file. (6) The chief of police shall set the permit fee which shall be the actual cost to the city for performing the permitting process. Upon payment of the required permit fee as determined by the Snellville Police Department and completing the questionnaire, the applicant shall be fingerprinted and photographed. The police department shall review the application and perform a criminal background check on the applicant for the purpose of ascertaining whether the applicant has pled to or has been convicted of a felony, or a misdemeanor involving violence or moral turpitude. A plea or conviction of a felony including a sentence imposed under the first offender statute, or a misdemeanor involving violence or moral turpitude shall disqualify the applicant. a. Within five working business days of application and after ascertaining that the questionnaire has been properly completed, and that the applicant has not been disqualified by virtue of prior pleas or conviction, the police department shall approve the application and will issue a solicitation permit badge. b. Each permit holder will be furnished a device suitable for attaching the solicitation permit badge to the outer clothing of the permit holder. No solicitor shall engage in any solicitation without wearing and displaying his/her solicitation permit badge in a conspicuous manner. (e) Penalty for violation of ordinance. It shall be a violation of this section: (1) For any person, business, partnership, corporation, association, organization, or a group of persons required by this section to have a permit to engage in any solicitation without first obtaining a permit or otherwise complying with the requirements of this section; (2) For any person to violate any of the provisions of this section or to violate any other city ordinance while engaging in any solicitation; (3) For any person to lend, rent or sell his permit card to another; (4) For any person to engage in any solicitation or canvassing between the hours of 9:00 p.m. during Daylight Savings Time and 9:00 a.m., or between 6:00 p.m. during Eastern Standard Time and 9:00 a.m., according to the standard time in effect at the time the violation is alleged to have occurred; (5) For more than two adult persons of 18 years of age or older to engage in solicitation on the same premises at the same time for the same goods or services; each individual member of a group engaged in solicitation in violation of this subsection shall be deemed to have violated the section; (6) For any person engaged in solicitation to misrepresent the purpose of his/her solicitation or use any false or deceptive statement or misrepresentation to induce a sale or contribution, or use any plan, scheme, or ruse which misrepresents the status or purpose of the person making the call; or (7) For any person to solicit or attempt to solicit at a place of residence at any entrance or part of the building other than the front door to the residence. (f) Exemptions. (1) Persons, businesses and organizations engaging in religious, nonprofit, charitable or political activities involving solicitation, shall be exempt. (2) Persons engaging in nonprofit organizations, school groups, and civic organizations shall be exempt from the requirements in this section. (3) Any person who calls upon prospective customers at their prior invitation shall be treated as exempt from the provisions of this section. (4) Any exempted persons are encouraged to optionally complete the requirements in this section to receive advice from the Snellville Police Department on safety and guidance while canvassing neighborhoods.
